docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials say New York City must be more specific about how it will protect the needs of people with H.I.V. or AIDS before the Government will approve the city's request to make managed care mandatory for most Medicaid recipients. Officials at the Health Care Financing Administration, which is considering the city's application, said last week that the agency was not ready to act on the request. A decision is expected by Oct. 31.

headline.main: U.S. Wants AIDS Care Detailed in H.M.O. Shift

docs.lead_paragraph: After receiving assurances that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut less than originally planned, the American Medical Association tonight expressed support for a House Republican proposal to redesign the medical plan for the elderly. Leaders of the association issued a statement after meeting with Speaker Newt Gingrich saying, "A.M.A. endorses House G.O.P. plan to transform Medicare."

headline.main: A.M.A. Backing Republicans In Plan to Overhaul Medicare

docs.snippet: After receiving assurances that Medicare payments to doctors would be cut less than originally planned, the American Medical Association tonight expressed support for a House Republican proposal to redesign the medical plan for the elderly.        ...

docs.lead_paragraph: At the Bond Hotel here, Lewis Osterman, 98, and Blanche M. Connor, 95, are living their last years in placid frugality. The couple met five years ago and now share all expenses 50-50, including the monthly $500 rent. They eat in for breakfast, skip lunch and have dinner at a nearby senior citizens center for $1.40 each. At that rate, Mr. Osterman figures, he can make savings last, to complement his Social Security check, until he is 110. "I came from a long-life family," he said. But he said the Republican plan to curb Medicare costs would eventually cost him at least $600 more a year in higher premiums, forcing him to depend solely on Social Security sooner and cutting a standard of living that now allows for an occasional dinner in a restaurant.

headline.main: In Florida, Retirees Watch Medicare Debate and Worry

docs.lead_paragraph: Pioneer Financial Services said today that it planned to buy the Universal Fidelity Life Insurance Company of Duncan, Okla., for about $26 million. The transaction is expected to close early next year, said the Schaumburg-based Pioneer Financial, a provider of life and health insurance. Universal Fidelity provides health insurance to the elderly.

headline.main: Worrying About the G.O.P. Medicare Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The symptoms were worrisome. They included agonizing abdominal and chest pains, spinal numbness from top to bottom, and a brilliant chartreuse rash from clavicle to kneecap. The prospects did not look good. I remembered William Saroyan's saying he always knew everybody had to die but thought an exception would be made in his case. That's the way I'd always felt. Now, though, the game was obviously over.

docs.lead_paragraph: For months, Republican plans to curb Federal health care spending have sailed along on a silent wave of interest group approval, or at least resignation, that seemed remarkable after the brawl over President Clinton's health care legislation. While Democrats denounced the plans, advocates for the elderly were all but silent. Doctors bought an advertisement praising the plan. The insurance industry approved. The hospitals stuck out in their unhappiness, but even they seemed to have toned it down since last spring.

headline.main: Silent for Months, Health Lobby Takes On G.O.P.

docs.lead_paragraph: Faculty members plan to put up informational picket lines tomorrow at eight state colleges and Montclair University, union leaders said yesterday. The Council of New Jersey State College Locals said it wanted to be prepared for a strike if a satisfactory agreement could not be reached in current contract negotiations. Donald Silberman, president of the council, said the state was proposing that salaries not be increased for for the life of the agreement and that employees pay more of their health insurance premiums, The Associated Press reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of debate, the Pataki administration has agreed to allow mothers for the first time to learn the results of AIDS tests given to all newborn babies.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A relentless criticism of health maintenance organizations like the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York is based upon the mistaken belief that a physician's discretion and use of professional judgment is not merely frowned upon by management but actually removed from health care providing abilities.
